sec.title: Acid deposition in a spruce forest soil: effects on nematodes, mycor ­ rhizas and fungal biomass
sec.p: Liliane Ruess 1 , Peter Sandbach 1, Pavel Cudlín 2, John Dighton 1, 3 and Alan Crossley 4
1 Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, Merlewood Research Station, Grange-over-Sands, Cumbria LA 11 6JU, UK

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Summary. The belowground biota (nematodes, fungal biomass, roots and mycorrhizal development) of a mature Sitka spruce stand under the influence of acid precipitation (equimolar sulphuric acid and ammonium nitrate) was investigated. Sampling took place after 3 years of treatment and 5 months after the end of treatment. Acidification led to a decrease of the soil pH from 5.0 to 4.0 in the upper 2 cm of soil. The active fungal biomass, measured as the ergosterol content of the soil, increased. After the end of the acid treatment pH differences decreased between plots. The active fungal biomass was lower, but the amount of total fungal hyphae was higher at the acid treated plots. Additionally, precipitation of acid mist led to an acceleration of fine root and mycorrhizal development and their senescence.

A total of 79 nematode species were found in the plots. Acidification caused a distinct decrease in species number, especially among K -strategists like omnivores and predators. The population density was not altered, but the dominance and abundance structure of the community changed.
Acrobeloides nanus
,
Metateratocephalus crassidens
and
Aphelenchoides spp.
showed a higher frequency at the acidified plots. Others, like
Cervidellus serratus ,
Filenchus spp.
or
Aporcelaimellus obtusicaudatus,
decreased. Among the trophic groups, the occurrence of omnivore and predatory nematodes was affected negatively by acidification. The proportion of fungal feeding nematodes increased under acid precipitation, but the effect did not last after the end of the treatment. This corresponds to the amount of the active fungal biomass measured in the soil, indicating that the composition of the nematode fauna is changing with the presence or absence of their food source.

sec.p: Key words: Spruce forest, acidification, nematodes, root density, fungal biomass, mycorrhiza

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Detailed studies dedicated to acid deposition effects on belowground plant parts and associated soil microflora and fauna are scarce. The aim of the present study is to investigate the influence of artificial acidification on nematode community structure in a spruce forest soil. By assessing the amount of fungi and roots, as an important nematode diet, direct effects of acidification and indirect effects via food supply can be determined. As there is need for appropriate indicator species in an ecotoxicological context (
) the use of nematodes for the evaluation on pollution effects in soil ecosystems is studied in this paper.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Site
Nematodes
Fungi

One gram soil samples (9 replicates per treatment), to be analysed for ergosterol content, were suspended in 30 ml methanol and transferred to 250 ml round bottom flasks and refluxed for 2 h. Afterwards they were filtered to remove soil particles and saponified with 5 ml of KOH (3.2%) in ethanol by refluxing for 30 min. When cooled, 10 ml H2O were added and the solutions were extracted 3 times with pentane (10, 5 and 5 ml). The pentane extracts were evaporated to dryness overnight (30 °C). The residues were redissolved in 1 ml methanol prior to quantification using a reverse-phase HPLC system at a wavelength of 282 nm.
Roots

Roots were separated from the sand by washing under a tap, over a sieve with mesh aperture 0.5 mm. Roots (cut into 50 mm length) and root fragments were randomly placed on a metal tray marked with grid lines. According to the generator of random numbers 5 grid squares were selected in different patterns. These representative root subsamples were immediately fixed in glutaraldehyde and divided into 2 categories, coarse roots (> 1 mm diameter) and fine roots (<1 mm diameter). The length of the fine roots was determined using the grid line intersect method of
.
Statistics

For statistical analysis a standard nonparametric and robust method, the Mann-Whitney U test, was used. With this test a pairwise ranking of treatments was made for the data obtained (e.g. fungal biomass, root length, nematode population density). The test of each pair does not depend on the other treatments in the study. This robust method was chosen, because with the lack of a random block design for sampling, a spatial pseudo replication of data occurred.

Additionally, linear regression analysis was carried out to investigate correlation between nematode community structure (e.g. trophic groups) and fungal biomass. Samples for root development were not taken into consideration, because they were not taken simultaneously with the other samples.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Soil parameters

Soil pH and water content of the investigated plots are given in Table 1 . After treatment with acid mist soil pH was clearly reduced. These effects were significant for all soil depths in October 1993. Changes were more obvious in the upper soil layer (0 — 2 cm), where the soil pH was 5.0 at the control and 4.0 at the acidified plots. Acid treatment stopped in November 1993, and differences in the pH decreased between plots. In April 1994 in 0 — 2 cm soil depth the pH was 4.9 at the control and 4.5 at the acidified plots. In deeper soil layers pH values were almost equal. Application of acid mist increased the soil water content in October 1993. No higher soil moisture was found in April 1994, after the end of the treatment.
Fungi

Total mycelial mass (hyphal length) and active fungal hyphae (ergosterol) were used to assess the fungal biomass in the soil (Fig. 1). Total and viable biomass showed differing vertical distribution in the soil. The ergosterol content decreased strongly with depth. More than 90 % of the ergosterol was concentrated in 0 — 2 cm soil layer, but only 59 to 66 % of the total fungal mycelia were found here as determined by hyphal length counts.
Roots
Nematodes

A total of 79 different species were found at the plots, of which 18 could only be determined to genus ( Table 3 ). Usually the occurrence of these 18 taxa was rare, making it difficult to assign them to described species. The classification into trophic groups was made according to
. Overall numbers of species were distributed differently. The bacterial feeders were the most common group with 33 species, followed by plant feeders with 22 species. The latter group includes mainly ectoparasites or epidermal cell and root hair feeders, but some migratory endoparasites or semiendoparasites were also observed. Other feeding types found were 9 fungal hyphae feeding species, 7 omnivores and 7 predators. Only one species belonged to the group of unicellular eucaryote feeders, which feed on diatoms or algae, as well as ingesting fungal spores or yeast cells. Eudominant (> 10%) on at least one sampling date and soil depth were the bacterial feeders
Acrobeloides nanus
,
Alaimus primitivus
and
Metateratocephalus crassidens,
the fungal feeder
Aphelenchoides macronucleatus,
and the ectoparasite
Cephalenchus megacephalus.

Acidification caused a decrease in the total number of species from 77 at the control plots to 62 at the acid mist plots ( Table 3 ). These effects were most evident among the omnivores and predators, where numbers were reduced to about half. The dominance structure of the different species varied between treatments. The occurrence of many bacterial feeding species was reduced after acid mist precipitation. Others, like
M. crassidens
, were more dominant. In particular some frequent fungal and plant feeders showed different distribution patterns. The fungal feeding species
Deladenus sp.
and
Diphtherophora vanoyei
made up to 5 % of the population at the control plots, but were not detected at the acid mist plots, where
Tylolaimophorus typicus
was more common. Among the plant feeders the genus
Filenchus
was negatively affected by acid treatment, but
Paratylenchus
and
Cephalenchus
seemed to gain importance. Almost all omnivore and predatory species were less dominant after acidification. In Table 4 species numbers in the different soil layers of the plots are given. Between 39 and 54 nematodes species were observed. Species numbers were higher at the control plots at all sampling dates and depths.

Acidification also influenced the abundance of species ( Table 6 ). Some taxa, like
A.
nanus,
M. crassidens
or
Aphelenchoides spp.
were more frequent at the acid mist plots, especially in the upper soil layer. After the end of the acid treatment the abundance of
M . crassidens
increased extremely to reach 87.6 Ind/g DW in 0 — 2 cm soil depth of the acid mist plots, compared to the control with 7.5 Ind/g DW. Other species were negatively affected by acid precipitation. The occurrence of
Cervidellus serratus
was lower at both sampling dates, while
Filenchus spp.
and
Aporcelaimellus obtusicaudatus
seemed to recover slowly in April 1994.

The proportions of omnivores, predators and unicellular eucaryote feeders were reduced after acidification at all sampling dates and depths. This decrease was significant (P <0.05) for the omnivore nematodes in 0 — 2 and 4 — 6 cm soil depth in October 1993 and in 0 — 2 cm soil depth in April 1994.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Most nematodes in forest soils feed on bacteria or fungi (
), and variations in pH affect their food source, the soil microorganisms.
reported that changes in nematode community structure are related to changes in the food availability and in consequence to microbial changes in the soil. Bacterial feeders were the most abundant group in the present plots. Their proportion of the nematode community was not altered by acidification, suggesting adequate bacterial food supply in the soil. This corresponds with results of
and
, who found relatively constant bacterial numbers but altered bacterial assemblages after acidification. As discussed above, the active fungal biomass was higher in the upper soil layer after acidification, but decreased after the end of the treatment. The same trend was shown by the fungal feeding nematodes. This indicates that the species composition of nematodes changes with the presence or absence of active fungal hyphae. In microcosm experiments
found changing fungal production in soil led to similar observations.

Most affected by acid treatment were omnivores and predators. Generally, these nematodes are K-strategists with low reproduction rate and long life-cycles (
).
and
report that especially the dorylaimid fauna is negatively affected by highly disturbed forest sites. In the present experiment their populations did not recover 5 months after the end of the acidification. They seem to be very sensitive to environmental disturbance and may be of good use as bioindicators in soil ecosystems.

In summary artificial acidification led to distinct changes in nematode community structure and to an increase of the active fungal biomass in the soil, which was followed by a shift towards fungal feeding nematodes. This shows that nematodes are interacting with other organisms or components in their soil environment. Variation in soil chemical properties, like the solution pH, will be reflected by the structure of the nematode community. Considering this, and the influence of nematodes in increasing the turnover of soil bacteria and fungi, and consequently plant nutrient cycling (see
) investigations of nematode-plant-microorganisms interactions are a central point in the future.
